awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Robotic University of Hawaii 88" Telescope (Robo88): A new tool for large surveys, rapid transient classification, and multimessenger astronomy
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop a robotic University of Hawaii 88" Telescope (Robo88) on Mauna Kea Hawaii, one of the premier astronomical sites in the world. Robo88 will bring new capabilities that will enable scientific investigations that are not currently feasible, including large systematic surveys of many targets distributed over the sky, studies of supernovae and other transients,  and rapid follow-up of gravitational wave sources, potentially hazardous near-earth asteroids, and stellar flares. The project will also support undergraduate research and training in the fast-evolving field of time domain astronomy. Through partnership with the Akamai Workforce Initiative, this project will broaden participation in science by engaging students from underrepresented populations.

Robo88 will be an agile robotic observatory with three instruments: 1) The Supernova Integral Field Spectrograph, a fully-integrated high-throughput instrument delivering one percent spectrophotometric observations for point sources even on structured backgrounds. 2) STACam, a 10K by 10K wide field-of-view imager. 3) Robo-AO-2, a robotic laser adaptive optics system that will deliver visible and infrared diffraction-limited imaging. Robo88 will bring new capabilities that will enable three new classes of scientific investigations not currently feasible: 1) Large systematic surveys (e.g., exoplanet host star characterization) that have many targets distributed over the sky that are otherwise not feasible on larger telescopes. 2) Rapid supernovae/transient classification of handfuls of interesting targets each night, that are otherwise inefficient on classically scheduled telescopes. 3) Near-immediate observations of quickly evolving or moving objects (e.g., gravitational wave sources, near-earth asteroids, stellar flares) that are only briefly visible once discovered.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Robotic University of Hawaii 88-inch Telescope (Robo88) is an exciting project that is modernizing the UH88 telescope, making it smarter, faster, and more efficient. Robo88 is transforming how astronomers study the universe, enabling the telescope to quickly capture and analyze short-lived, dramatic events in space like exploding stars, cosmic collisions, and other extraordinary phenomena. These upgrades are helping ensure that the UH88 telescope remains an essential tool for exploring the cosmos.

What Makes Robo88 Special?

At the heart of Robo88 are three incredible instruments:

  1. SNIFS (Supernova Integral Field Spectrograph): A tool designed to study supernovae with extreme precision, enabling their use as cosmological probes to explore the universe's expansion and dark energy.

  2. STACam: A wide-field imager used to determine the orbits of potentially habitable asteroids, including those that could pose a threat to Earth.

  3. Robo-AO-2: A cutting-edge system that uses lasers to create ultra-sharp images of stars and planets, even from the ground.

The project has also developed a robotic scheduler—an intelligent system for the telescope—that decides what to observe and when, ensuring that time is used as efficiently as possible. While work is still underway to fully integrate all these systems, major progress has been made, and the telescope is already operating in a partially robotic mode.

Why Does This Matter?

Robo88 is designed to answer big questions about the universe. By making the UH88 telescope more automated and responsive, it can observe events that happen quickly and are hard to predict, such as stellar explosions or gravitational wave detections. These observations give us clues about the origins of stars, planets, and even the universe itself.

The telescope’s ability to run automatically also means it can handle large-scale surveys, like studying thousands of stars to learn more about the planets orbiting them or quickly classifying new objects in the sky to help astronomers worldwide decide what to focus on next.

Beyond the Science

Robo88 isn’t just for researchers. It’s also a powerful educational tool. Students at the University of Hawaii and beyond are learning how to use this advanced technology to conduct their own studies. The telescope has already supported the work of many graduate students and summer interns, giving them valuable hands-on experience that will prepare them for careers in science, engineering, and technology.

Undergraduate students are also benefiting. For example, classes at the University of Hawaii are using Robo88 to observe and analyze stars and galaxies, combining learning with real-world research. This gives students a unique opportunity to see what it’s like to be an astronomer.

Looking to the Future

The goal is to make Robo88 fully robotic by 2025. Once complete, the telescope will be even more capable of tackling the mysteries of the universe, from studying distant galaxies to observing fleeting cosmic events. This transformation is a great example of how updating older equipment with modern technology can breathe new life into valuable scientific tools.

By supporting both cutting-edge research and inspiring the next generation of scientists, Robo88 is helping to ensure a bright future for astronomy and science education. Its contributions will continue to expand our understanding of the universe and inspire curiosity for years to come.
